segment.source: How is a PIN different from (and better than) a password?
segment.target: How is a PIN different from (and better than) a password?

segment.source: On the surface, a PIN looks much like a password.
segment.target: On the surface, a PIN looks much like a password.

segment.source: A PIN can be a set of numbers, but enterprise policy might allow complex PINs that include special characters and letters, both upper-case and lower-case.
segment.target: A PIN can be a set of numbers, but enterprise policy might allow complex PINs that include special characters and letters, both upper-case and lower-case.

segment.source: Something like t758A!
segment.target: Something like t758A!

segment.source: could be an account password or a complex Passport PIN.
segment.target: could be an account password or a complex Passport PIN.

segment.source: It isn't the structure of a PIN (length, complexity) that makes it better than a password, it's how it works.
segment.target: It isn't the structure of a PIN (length, complexity) that makes it better than a password, it's how it works.

segment.source: PIN is tied to the device
segment.target: PIN is tied to the device

segment.source: One important difference between a password and a Passport PIN is that the PIN is tied to the specific device on which it was set up.
segment.target: One important difference between a password and a Passport PIN is that the PIN is tied to the specific device on which it was set up.

segment.source: That PIN is useless to anyone without that specific hardware.
segment.target: That PIN is useless to anyone without that specific hardware.

segment.source: Someone who steals your password can sign in to your account from anywhere, but if they steal your PIN, they'd have to steal your physical device too!
segment.target: Someone who steals your password can sign in to your account from anywhere, but if they steal your PIN, they'd have to steal your physical device too!

segment.source: Even you can't use that PIN anywhere except on that specific device.
segment.target: Even you can't use that PIN anywhere except on that specific device.

segment.source: If you want to sign in on multiple devices, you have to set up Passport on each device.
segment.target: If you want to sign in on multiple devices, you have to set up Passport on each device.

segment.source: PIN is local to the device
segment.target: PIN is local to the device

segment.source: A password is transmitted to the server -- it can be intercepted in transmission or stolen from a server.
segment.target: A password is transmitted to the server -- it can be intercepted in transmission or stolen from a server.

segment.source: A PIN is local to the device -- it isn't transmitted anywhere and it isn't stored on the server.
segment.target: A PIN is local to the device -- it isn't transmitted anywhere and it isn't stored on the server.

segment.source: When the PIN is created, it establishes a trusted relationship with the identity provider and creates an asymmetric key pair that is used for authentication.
segment.target: When the PIN is created, it establishes a trusted relationship with the identity provider and creates an asymmetric key pair that is used for authentication.

segment.source: When you enter your PIN, it unlocks the authentication key and uses the key to sign the request that is sent to the authenticating server.
segment.target: When you enter your PIN, it unlocks the authentication key and uses the key to sign the request that is sent to the authenticating server.

segment.source: Note: For details on how Passport uses asymetric key pairs for authentication, see Microsoft Passport guide.
segment.target: Note: For details on how Passport uses asymetric key pairs for authentication, see Microsoft Passport guide.

segment.source: PIN is backed by hardware
segment.target: PIN is backed by hardware

segment.source: The Passport PIN is backed by a Trusted Platform Module (TPM) chip, which is a secure crypto-processor that is designed to carry out cryptographic operations.
segment.target: The Passport PIN is backed by a Trusted Platform Module (TPM) chip, which is a secure crypto-processor that is designed to carry out cryptographic operations.

segment.source: The chip includes multiple physical security mechanisms to make it tamper resistant, and malicious software is unable to tamper with the security functions of the TPM.
segment.target: The chip includes multiple physical security mechanisms to make it tamper resistant, and malicious software is unable to tamper with the security functions of the TPM.

segment.source: All Windows 10 Mobile phones and many modern laptops have TPM.
segment.target: All Windows 10 Mobile phones and many modern laptops have TPM.

segment.source: User key material is generated and available within the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) of the user device, which protects it from attackers who want to capture the key material and reuse it.
segment.target: User key material is generated and available within the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) of the user device, which protects it from attackers who want to capture the key material and reuse it.

segment.source: Because Microsoft Passport uses asymmetrical key pairs, users credentials can’t be stolen in cases where the identity provider or websites the user accesses have been compromised.
segment.target: Because Microsoft Passport uses asymmetrical key pairs, users credentials can’t be stolen in cases where the identity provider or websites the user accesses have been compromised.

segment.source: The TPM protects against a variety of known and potential attacks, including PIN brute-force attacks.
segment.target: The TPM protects against a variety of known and potential attacks, including PIN brute-force attacks.

segment.source: After too many incorrect guesses, the device is locked.
segment.target: After too many incorrect guesses, the device is locked.

segment.source: The Passport PIN is subject to the same set of IT management policies as a password, such as complexity, length, expiration, and history.
segment.target: The Passport PIN is subject to the same set of IT management policies as a password, such as complexity, length, expiration, and history.

segment.source: Although we generally think of a PIN as a simple four-digit code, administrators can set policies for managed devices to require a PIN complexity similar to a password.
segment.target: Although we generally think of a PIN as a simple four-digit code, administrators can set policies for managed devices to require a PIN complexity similar to a password.

segment.source: You can require or block: special characters, uppercase characters, lowercase characters, and digits.

segment.source: What if someone steals the laptop or phone?
segment.target: What if someone steals the laptop or phone?

segment.source: To compromise a Microsoft Passport credential that TPM protects, an attacker must have access to the physical device, and then must find a way to spoof the user’s biometrics or guess his or her PIN—and all of this must be done before TPM anti-hammer capabilities lock the device.
segment.target: To compromise a Microsoft Passport credential that TPM protects, an attacker must have access to the physical device, and then must find a way to spoof the user’s biometrics or guess his or her PIN—and all of this must be done before TPM anti-hammer capabilities lock the device.

segment.source: You can provide additional protection for laptops that don't have TPM by enablng BitLocker and setting a policy to limit failed sign-ins.
segment.target: You can provide additional protection for laptops that don't have TPM by enablng BitLocker and setting a policy to limit failed sign-ins.

segment.source: Why do you need a PIN to use Windows Hello?
segment.target: Why do you need a PIN to use Windows Hello?

segment.source: Windows Hello is the biometric sign-in for Microsoft Passport in Windows 10: fingerprint, iris, or facial recognition.
segment.target: Windows Hello is the biometric sign-in for Microsoft Passport in Windows 10: fingerprint, iris, or facial recognition.

segment.source: When you set up Windows Hello, you're asked to create a PIN first.
segment.target: When you set up Windows Hello, you're asked to create a PIN first.

segment.source: This PIN enables you to sign in using Passport when you can’t use your preferred biometric because of an injury or because the sensor is unavailable or not working properly.
segment.target: This PIN enables you to sign in using Passport when you can’t use your preferred biometric because of an injury or because the sensor is unavailable or not working properly.

segment.source: If you only had a biometric sign-in configured and, for any reason, were unable to use that method to sign in, you would have to sign in using your account name and password, which doesn't provide you the same level of protection as Passport.
segment.target: If you only had a biometric sign-in configured and, for any reason, were unable to use that method to sign in, you would have to sign in using your account name and password, which doesn't provide you the same level of protection as Passport.
